title: Switzerland's citizens want a circular economy, but not to share products - Phys.org
summary: Swiss people think highly of the circular economy but don't always implement it in their daily lives. The majority support political measures to promote circular economy, but they prefer to buy new products instead of sharing or buying second-hand. There is room for maneuver for policymakers to encourage circular behaviors.

title: Circular economy: the rule of the three R's... or seven? - CEPSA.com
summary: The circular economy is a production model that aims to minimize waste and conserve natural resources by reusing and recycling materials. The circular economy has many benefits for the environment and sustainable development, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions, conserving natural resources, and creating jobs. The Spanish government has passed a law to promote the transition to a circular economy in the country.

green_product: TRUE; The circular economy promotes the use of green products, which are designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces their environmental impact throughout their life cycle.
green_process: TRUE; The circular economy promotes the use of green processes, which are methods or techniques in manufacturing, production, or any other operational activity that minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability.

title: Sustainable food industry solutions for the future - The Washington Post
summary: Tetra Pak is working towards a circular economy in the food packaging industry by exploring new materials and food sources, and collaborating with other players in the food industry.   The company is exploring graphene composites to make the next generation of equipment lighter and more energy efficient, and is working with EnginZyme to develop technology for increased sustainability of production processes.  Tetra Pak is also collaborating with the University of Modena and Reggio Emilia (UNIMORE) to research human-machine interaction to design machinery that is better tailored to the needs of human operators.

title: Recycling project builds a thirst for sustainable housing - Media Statements
summary: The Federal and Queensland Labor Governments have announced saveBOARD will establish its first Queensland facility on the Gold Coast, thanks to more than $1.7 million in grant funding from the Queensland Recycling Modernisation Fund (QRMF). saveBOARD’s project will transform waste, including coffee cups, used beverage cartons, such as juice poppers, and soft plastics into high-performance building materials. Its new facility will divert used beverage cartons collected through the Container Exchange refund points, soft plastics and other mixed fibre materials such as coffee cups into low-carbon building products that are substitutes for plaster board, particle board and plywood.

title: How damaged, discontinued and returned goods are being saved from landfill - Nine Shows
summary: Circonomy, a social enterprise in Melbourne and Brisbane, sells new products for half the price by refurbishing millions of kilograms of damaged, discontinued and returned goods that would otherwise end up in landfill. Circonomy works with major brands and retailers to obtain excess stock, customer returns, damaged or imperfect products, and clearance products that would otherwise be thrown away. Circonomy refurbishes the items and sells them for up to 70% off.

green_process: TRUE. Circonomy's refurbishment process minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability by reducing waste, conserving natural resources, decreasing energy consumption, and ensuring that products are biodegradable or easily recyclable at the end of their life cycle.
